yes sir this is a letter that
commissioner campbell wrote to mr
phillip may of president of energy
louisiana it's dated june 14th of 2022
and it says dear mr may i am writing to
you regarding a recent letter that you
sent to your customers explaining the
basis for increases in their electric
bills one reason given for the increased
cost is your recovery of storm
restoration cost your letter stated that
the louisiana public service commission
approved your plan to securitize those
costs earlier this year while the
commission did approve your
securitization plan that is not the
whole story as you will recall the vote
taken at the february lpsc meeting in
docket
u35991 was a four to one vote with my
objections to the approval stated on the
record while i generally support
securitization of storm restoration
costs as a means to lower cost to
ratepayers i voted against your request
for two reasons first the storm repairs
for the hurricanes from the hurricanes
occurred primarily in south louisiana
but entergy's plan has customers in
north louisiana paying for those repairs
even though they were not affected by
the storms my second and stronger
objection was that energy shareholders
were not sharing in the payment of storm
cost i directed staff to investigate
alternative methods to allocate storm
restoration costs to different
geographical areas and to investigate
whether utility shareholders can be
required to share in restoration cost
your failure to disclose that there was
a dissenting vote in your notice to
customers has left many of my
constituents in north louisiana confused
as many are aware of the concerns i've
voiced at the february and subsequent
meetings as a result i have been
receiving numerous complaints from my
constituents about the rate increase and
my vote i would like for energy to
disclose the vote in a future notice to
its customers in north louisiana and i
would like to discuss with you how best
to clear up the confusion your recent
notice has created with my constituents
please give me a call to discuss at your
earliest convenience thank you for
assistance and cooperation in this
matter sincerely foster campbell

submit proof of said payments to the
commission within 10 days of making
those payments lastly the commission
staff requested that the carrier be
assessed a 500 fine pursuant to the
commission's general order dated
november 22nd of 2011 and the carrier be
assessed to 25 citation fee pursuant to
the commission's general order dated
june 7 2006. in support of its case the
commission staff presented the
testimonies of transportation
administrator tammy burrell and audit
director robin pendergrass according to
ms pendergrass's testimony the
commission's auditing division conducted
an audit of the carrier between 2016 and
2022 and that audit revealed that for
the years 15 17 18 19 and 20 the
carrier's total regulated revenues as
reported in its inspection and
supervision fee filings with the
department of revenue did not match its
total regulated revenues as reported its
annual reports ms pendergrass prepared
an audit memorandum for ms burrell and
ms bruhl confirmed that the carrier's
reported revenues were not consistent
for the aforementioned years a hearing
was conducted on may 5th of 2022 where
the carrier failed to appear at the
hearing and presented defense the
administrative law just concluded that
the carrier reported revenues for the
years 15 17 18 19 and 20 did not match
the revenues reported to the louisiana
department of revenue louisiana via
statute 45 1177 requires that each
commission regulated motor carrier paid
to the state through the louisiana
department of revenue
a fee for the inspection control and
supervision of the carrier's business
services and rates per revised statute
45 1179 this fee is calculated using the
revenues reported in the carrier's
annual report however in computing and
suspection and supervision vision fees
it appears that the carrier user revenue
is reported to the department of revenue
as there is a discrepancy between the
amount reported to the department of
revenue and the amount reported to the
annual course the carrier did not pay a
properly calculated fee to the state for
the years 15 17 18 19 and 20.
accordingly the administrative law just
concluded that the carrier is guilty of
violating louisiana revised statute
based on the evidence and testimony
presented at the hearing the
administrative law judge recommends that
one ian nelson dba ian's autobody in
towing be found guilty of violating
louisiana by statute 45 1177 by failing
to pay the properly calculated
inspection supervision fees to the state
for the years 15 17 18 19 and 20. two
that ian nelson dbas ian auto's body and
towing be required to ascertain the
correct gross revenues for the years 15
17 18 19 and 20. report the correct
gross repeats for the years 15 17 18 19
and 20 and amend any associated filings
within 60 days of the date of the
issuance of this order
but ian nelson dba ian's auto body and
towing be required to provide proof to
the commission that it reported the
correct gross receipts and amended any
associated filings within 10 days of
such corrections that a fine of 500 be
imposed upon ian nelson dba ian's auto
body and towing preferred to pay the
appropriate inspection supervision fees
for the years 15 17 18 19 and 20 and
that this amount must be paid to the
commission in certified funds within 60
days of the date of the issuance of this
order and five that the citation fee of
25 dollars be imposed upon ian nelson
dba ian's auto body and towing and that
this amount be paid to the commission in
certified funds within 60 days of the
date of issuance of this order
